era.name: Apostolic Era
era.description: The foundational period of Christianity, spanning from the birth of Jesus of Nazareth through the death of the last apostle. This era witnessed the emergence of Christianity from within Second Temple Judaism, the establishment of the early church, and the beginning of the parting of ways between Judaism and Christianity.
era.christianity_status: Emergence from Judaism; spread throughout Roman Empire; development of core doctrines
era.judaism_status: Second Temple period; destruction of Temple in 70 AD; emergence of Rabbinic Judaism

events.title: Birth of Jesus
events.summary: Birth of Jesus of Nazareth during the reign of Herod the Great.
events.detailed_narrative: Jesus was born in Bethlehem during the reign of Herod the Great, under Roman occupation. According to the Gospels, Mary and Joseph traveled from Nazareth to Bethlehem due to a census. The birth fulfilled prophecies including Micah 5:2 regarding the Messiah's birth in Bethlehem.
events.significance: The incarnation of the Son of God according to Christian theology; the birth of the central figure of Christianity.
events.scholarly_consensus: Most scholars date Jesus's birth to c. 6-4 BC based on Herod's death in 4 BC. The exact date and circumstances are debated.

interpretations.orthodox: The incarnation of the eternal Word of God, initiating the salvation of humanity through theosis.
interpretations.catholic: The Incarnation - God becoming man through the Virgin Mary, Theotokos.
interpretations.protestant: God taking on human flesh to accomplish redemption; fulfillment of Old Testament prophecy.
interpretations.jewish: Birth of a Jewish teacher; not recognized as Messiah; historical figure.
interpretations.academic: Historical birth of Jesus of Nazareth; details in Gospel accounts shaped by theological concerns.

events.title: Ministry of John the Baptist
events.summary: John the Baptist's prophetic ministry calling Israel to repentance through baptism.
events.detailed_narrative: John appeared as an apocalyptic preacher in the Judean wilderness, calling Israel to repentance and baptizing in the Jordan River. He prepared the way for Jesus and baptized him. His ministry attracted large crowds and attention from religious authorities.
events.significance: Last of the Old Testament prophetic tradition; prepared the way for Jesus's ministry.
events.scholarly_consensus: Josephus independently confirms John's existence and execution by Herod Antipas (Antiquities 18.5.2).

interpretations.orthodox: The Forerunner who prepared the way for the Messiah; last prophet of the Old Covenant.
interpretations.catholic: The precursor of Christ; model of ascetic life and prophetic witness.
interpretations.protestant: Prophet who prepared Israel for the Messiah; emphasized repentance and faith.
interpretations.jewish: Historical figure; apocalyptic preacher within Second Temple Jewish diversity.
interpretations.academic: Apocalyptic Jewish prophet; possible connections to Essene community.

events.title: Jesus's Public Ministry
events.summary: Approximately three years of teaching, healing, and proclaiming the Kingdom of God.
events.detailed_narrative: Jesus's ministry included teaching (Sermon on the Mount, parables), miracle-working (healings, exorcisms, nature miracles), gathering disciples, and proclaiming the arrival of God's Kingdom. He engaged in controversies with religious authorities over Sabbath observance, purity laws, and claims to divine authority.
events.significance: Foundation of Christian faith and practice; teachings that would shape Western civilization.
events.scholarly_consensus: Ministry occurred during Pilate's prefecture (26-36 AD). Length and chronology debated; typically 1-3 years.

interpretations.orthodox: The earthly ministry of the incarnate Logos, revealing God and effecting salvation.
interpretations.catholic: Christ's public ministry establishing the Church and the means of grace.
interpretations.protestant: Jesus's authoritative teaching and redemptive mission; model for discipleship.
interpretations.jewish: Ministry of a Jewish teacher/healer; claims evaluated against Jewish messianic expectations.
interpretations.academic: Ministry of an itinerant Jewish teacher; apocalyptic prophet or wisdom teacher debates.

events.title: Crucifixion and Resurrection
events.summary: Jesus's execution by crucifixion and resurrection on the third day.
events.detailed_narrative: Jesus was arrested, tried before Jewish and Roman authorities, and executed by crucifixion under Pontius Pilate. According to Christian faith, he rose from the dead on the third day and appeared to his disciples over forty days before ascending to heaven.
events.significance: Central event of Christian faith; the atoning death and vindicating resurrection of Jesus.
events.scholarly_consensus: Crucifixion under Pilate is well-attested (Tacitus, Josephus). Resurrection is a matter of faith; emergence of resurrection belief requires historical explanation.

interpretations.orthodox: The Paschal Mystery - Christ's victory over death, opening the path to theosis.
interpretations.catholic: Redemptive sacrifice for humanity's sins; foundation of the sacramental system.
interpretations.protestant: Penal substitutionary atonement; justification through faith in Christ's finished work.
interpretations.jewish: Death of Jesus; resurrection not accepted; did not fulfill messianic expectations.
interpretations.academic: Crucifixion historical; resurrection belief among disciples is significant phenomenon requiring explanation.

events.title: Pentecost
events.summary: Outpouring of the Holy Spirit on the disciples; birth of the church.
events.detailed_narrative: Fifty days after Passover, during the Jewish festival of Shavuot, the Holy Spirit descended on the gathered disciples. They spoke in languages understood by Jewish pilgrims from throughout the Diaspora. Peter preached and about 3,000 were baptized.
events.significance: The empowering of the church for mission; fulfillment of Joel 2:28-32.
events.scholarly_consensus: Events described in Acts 2 reflect early church's understanding of Spirit-empowerment. Historical core debated.

interpretations.orthodox: Descent of the Holy Spirit completing the Trinity's revelation; birth of the Church.
interpretations.catholic: The Church's birthday; empowerment for mission and witness.
interpretations.protestant: Fulfillment of Jesus's promise of the Spirit; empowerment for gospel proclamation.
interpretations.jewish: Not part of Jewish tradition; Shavuot celebrates Torah giving at Sinai.
interpretations.academic: Foundational narrative for early church self-understanding; reflects Luke's theology.

events.title: Stoning of Stephen
events.summary: First Christian martyr; triggered persecution and scattering of believers.
events.detailed_narrative: Stephen, a Hellenistic Jewish Christian deacon, was arrested for his preaching. His speech before the Sanhedrin critiqued Israel's history of rejecting God's messengers. He was stoned to death, becoming the first Christian martyr.
events.significance: First Christian martyrdom; persecution scattered church, spreading the gospel.
events.scholarly_consensus: Martyrdom historically plausible; speech in Acts 7 may reflect early Christian interpretation of Israel's history.
scripture_used: Various Old Testament passages in Stephen's speech

interpretations.orthodox: Protomartyr; model of faithful witness unto death; sees Christ at God's right hand.
interpretations.catholic: First martyr; patron saint; model of forgiveness of persecutors.
interpretations.protestant: Faithful witness; example of Spirit-empowered testimony; catalyst for mission.
interpretations.jewish: Execution of a perceived blasphemer within historical context.
interpretations.academic: Early instance of intra-Jewish conflict over Jesus movement.

events.title: Conversion of Paul
events.summary: Dramatic conversion of Christianity's chief persecutor into its greatest missionary.
events.detailed_narrative: Saul of Tarsus, a Pharisee who persecuted Christians, experienced a vision of the risen Christ on the road to Damascus. Blinded and then healed, he was baptized and began preaching Jesus as Messiah.
events.significance: Transformation of persecutor into apostle; pivotal for Gentile mission and Christian theology.
events.scholarly_consensus: Paul's conversion is historically certain; nature of experience debated (vision, psychological, revelatory).

interpretations.orthodox: Divine call to apostleship; encounter with the risen Lord.
interpretations.catholic: Model of conversion and divine grace; call to apostolic mission.
interpretations.protestant: Paradigm of conversion by grace; call apart from human works.
interpretations.jewish: Apostasy from Judaism; departure from ancestral faith.
interpretations.academic: Significant religious experience; transformation from opponent to adherent.

events.title: Council of Jerusalem
events.summary: First church council deciding Gentile converts did not need circumcision.
events.detailed_narrative: As Gentiles joined the church through Paul's mission, debate arose about Torah observance. The council, led by James, Peter, and Paul, determined that Gentiles need not be circumcised but should observe minimal requirements (abstain from idolatry, sexual immorality, strangled meat, blood).
events.significance: Established framework for Jew-Gentile relations; decisive for Christianity's universal scope.
events.scholarly_consensus: Historicity debated; relationship between Acts 15 and Galatians 2 unclear. Represents significant early church decision-making.

interpretations.orthodox: First ecumenical decision; Spirit-guided conciliarity; model for future councils.
interpretations.catholic: Exercise of apostolic authority; precedent for magisterial teaching.
interpretations.protestant: Affirmation of gospel of grace; salvation by faith, not works of law.
interpretations.jewish: Moment of decisive break; Christianity becomes separate from Judaism.
interpretations.academic: Compromise solution to internal conflict; significant for Christian identity formation.

events.title: Paul's Missionary Journeys
events.summary: Three missionary journeys establishing churches throughout the Roman Empire.
events.detailed_narrative: Paul conducted three major missionary journeys: (1) Cyprus and South Galatia (46-48 AD); (2) Greece and Asia Minor (49-52 AD); (3) Ephesus and Greece (53-57 AD). He also journeyed to Rome as a prisoner (59-62 AD). He established churches and wrote letters that became scripture.
events.significance: Spread Christianity throughout Roman Empire; theological development through epistles.
events.scholarly_consensus: Journeys generally accepted; chronology reconstructed from Acts and epistles with some debate.

interpretations.orthodox: Apostolic mission fulfilling Christ's commission; establishment of local churches.
interpretations.catholic: Evangelization of the nations; founding of churches under apostolic authority.
interpretations.protestant: Model of missionary work; gospel proclamation and church planting.
interpretations.jewish: Spread of Christianity outside Judaism; development of separate religion.
interpretations.academic: Urban mission strategy; social networks and patronage in early Christianity.

events.title: Destruction of the Temple
events.summary: Roman destruction of the Second Temple, ending Jewish sacrificial worship.
events.detailed_narrative: The First Jewish-Roman War (66-73 AD) culminated in the Roman siege and destruction of Jerusalem under General Titus. The Temple, center of Jewish religious life, was burned and demolished on the 9th of Av (August 70 AD). This catastrophic event transformed both Judaism and Christianity.
events.significance: End of Temple worship; transformation of Judaism; acceleration of Jewish-Christian separation.
events.scholarly_consensus: Well-documented event; Josephus provides eyewitness account. Archaeological evidence confirms destruction.

interpretations.orthodox: Fulfillment of prophecy; end of Old Covenant sacrifices; church becomes new Temple.
interpretations.catholic: Divine judgment confirming New Covenant; Christ's sacrifice supersedes Temple.
interpretations.protestant: Prophetic fulfillment; end of ceremonial law; validation of Christianity.
interpretations.jewish: Churban (catastrophe); mourned on Tisha B'Av; beginning of exile; transformation to Rabbinic Judaism.
interpretations.academic: Major historical event; reshaped both religions; Josephus primary source.

events.title: Writing of the Gospels
events.summary: Oral traditions about Jesus committed to writing in four canonical Gospels.
events.detailed_narrative: The four canonical Gospels emerged from oral traditions in early Christian communities. Mark (c. 65-70), Matthew (c. 70-85), Luke (c. 75-85), and John (c. 90-100) each present distinctive perspectives on Jesus's life and teaching.
events.significance: Preservation of Jesus traditions; foundation of Christian scripture; diversity within unity.
events.scholarly_consensus: Markan priority generally accepted; Q hypothesis for Matthew-Luke common material; John independent tradition.

interpretations.orthodox: Spirit-inspired scriptures; four perspectives on the one Christ.
interpretations.catholic: Apostolic witness preserved; inerrant scripture within Tradition.
interpretations.protestant: God-breathed scripture; sufficient authority for faith and practice.
interpretations.jewish: Christian texts about Jesus; not part of Jewish canon.
interpretations.academic: Literary products of early Christian communities; sources for historical Jesus research.

events.title: Persecution under Nero
events.summary: First official Roman persecution of Christians following the Great Fire of Rome.
events.detailed_narrative: After the Great Fire of Rome (64 AD), Emperor Nero blamed Christians. Tacitus describes horrific punishments: Christians covered in animal skins and torn by dogs, crucified, and set ablaze as human torches. Tradition holds Peter and Paul were martyred during this persecution.
events.significance: First state persecution; martyrdom of Peter and Paul; established precedent for later persecutions.
events.scholarly_consensus: Persecution well-attested (Tacitus Annals 15.44). Martyrdom of Peter and Paul in Rome accepted by most scholars.

interpretations.orthodox: Witness of martyrs; blood of martyrs as seed of church.
interpretations.catholic: Persecution confirming faith; martyrdom of Peter in Rome supports papal claims.
interpretations.protestant: Cost of discipleship; faithfulness unto death; persecution as mark of true church.
interpretations.jewish: Roman persecution of another group; parallels with later Jewish persecution.
interpretations.academic: Scapegoating of minority group; social-political dynamics of persecution.

events.title: Fall of Masada
events.summary: Final act of the First Jewish-Roman War; mass suicide of Jewish defenders.
events.detailed_narrative: After Jerusalem's fall, the last Jewish rebels held out at the fortress of Masada until 73 AD. When Roman forces finally breached the walls, they found that most defenders (960 people according to Josephus) had committed mass suicide rather than be captured.
events.significance: End of the First Jewish-Roman War; symbol of Jewish resistance in modern Israel.
events.scholarly_consensus: Archaeological excavations confirm siege; mass suicide narrative debated but plausible.

interpretations.orthodox: Historical event; not specifically theological significance.
interpretations.catholic: Historical tragedy; moral complexity of suicide.
interpretations.protestant: Historical event; sometimes cited in discussions of religious liberty.
interpretations.jewish: Symbol of Jewish resistance; commemorated in modern Israel; complex ethical legacy.
interpretations.academic: Archaeological and literary evidence align; significance for Jewish identity.

events.title: Council of Jamnia
events.summary: Traditional date for consolidation of Hebrew canon and restructuring of Judaism.
events.detailed_narrative: Following the Temple's destruction, Rabban Yochanan ben Zakkai established an academy at Yavneh (Jamnia). Traditional view held this 'council' fixed the Hebrew Bible canon. Modern scholarship sees this as gradual process rather than single event.
events.significance: Formation of Rabbinic Judaism; development of Jewish canon; post-Temple Jewish identity.
events.scholarly_consensus: Concept of formal 'Council of Jamnia' largely abandoned; academy important but canon formation was gradual.

interpretations.orthodox: Jewish development; parallel to Christian canon formation.
interpretations.catholic: Jewish canon formation; different from broader Catholic Old Testament.
interpretations.protestant: Relevant to understanding Hebrew canon that Protestants follow.
interpretations.jewish: Crucial moment in Jewish survival; Yavneh saved Judaism through Torah study.
interpretations.academic: Academy at Yavneh important; 'council' concept outdated; gradual canon formation.

events.title: Death of John the Apostle
events.summary: Death of the last apostle; end of the apostolic era.
events.detailed_narrative: According to church tradition, John the Apostle lived to an advanced age in Ephesus, outliving all other apostles. He is credited with writing the Gospel of John, three epistles, and Revelation. He died during Emperor Trajan's reign (98-117 AD).
events.significance: End of apostolic era; transition to sub-apostolic period; closure of apostolic witness.
events.scholarly_consensus: Tradition of John in Ephesus early and widespread (Irenaeus); authorship of Johannine corpus debated.

interpretations.orthodox: End of apostolic age; Tradition now carries apostolic witness.
interpretations.catholic: Closure of revelation; apostolic succession continues teaching authority.
interpretations.protestant: End of foundational generation; Scripture complete and sufficient.
interpretations.jewish: Death of early Christian leader; not directly relevant.
interpretations.academic: Traditional date; marks transition in early Christian history.

figures.name: Jesus of Nazareth
figures.biography: Central figure of Christianity. Born in Bethlehem, raised in Nazareth. Conducted public ministry of teaching, healing, and proclaiming God's Kingdom. Crucified under Pontius Pilate, believed by Christians to have risen from the dead.
key_contributions: Proclamation of the Kingdom of God
Sermon on the Mount and ethical teaching

figures.name: Simon Peter
figures.biography: Originally a fisherman from Bethsaida. Part of Jesus's inner circle. Despite denying Jesus, became leader of the Jerusalem church. Traditionally martyred in Rome under Nero.

figures.name: Paul of Tarsus
figures.biography: Born a Pharisee in Tarsus, educated under Gamaliel. Initially persecuted Christians. Converted on Damascus road. Conducted missionary journeys establishing churches. Wrote numerous epistles. Martyred in Rome.

figures.name: James, Brother of Jesus
figures.biography: Brother of Jesus who became believer after resurrection. Led Jerusalem church. Presided over Council of Jerusalem. Authored Epistle of James. Martyred in 62 AD according to Josephus.

figures.name: John the Apostle
figures.biography: Son of Zebedee, brother of James. Part of Jesus's inner circle. Traditionally 'the disciple whom Jesus loved.' Lived to old age in Ephesus. Authored Gospel, epistles, and Revelation.

figures.name: Mary, Mother of Jesus
figures.biography: Young woman from Nazareth betrothed to Joseph. Conceived Jesus by the Holy Spirit according to Gospels. Present at crucifixion and Pentecost. Venerated especially in Orthodox and Catholic traditions.
key_contributions: Present at key moments in Christ's life

figures.name: Stephen
figures.biography: One of seven Hellenistic Jewish Christian deacons. Powerful preacher and miracle worker. Arrested for alleged blasphemy. Delivered speech before Sanhedrin. Stoned to death, becoming first Christian martyr.

figures.name: Barnabas
figures.biography: Levite from Cyprus originally named Joseph, called Barnabas ('son of encouragement'). Introduced Paul to Jerusalem apostles. Accompanied Paul on first missionary journey. Later worked independently in Cyprus.
controversies: Separation from Paul over John Mark

figures.name: Flavius Josephus
figures.biography: Jewish priest and military leader who surrendered to Romans during Jewish War. Became Roman citizen under Flavian patronage. Wrote major historical works providing crucial information about first-century Judaism and early Christianity.
key_contributions: Independent attestation to Jesus, John the Baptist, James
controversies: Viewed as traitor by some Jews

figures.name: Gamaliel I
figures.biography: Grandson of Hillel, leading Pharisaic teacher and Sanhedrin member. Remembered for counsel regarding early Christians and as Paul's teacher. Honored in Jewish tradition as one of the greatest sages.

scripture_usage.passage_text: Who hath believed our report? and to whom is the arm of the LORD revealed? For he shall grow up before him as a tender plant, and as a root out of a dry ground... He was despised and rejected of men; a man of sorrows, and acquainted with grief... Surely he hath borne our griefs, and carried our sorrows... But he was wounded for our transgressions, he was bruised for our iniquities: the chastisement of our peace was upon him; and with his stripes we are healed.
scripture_usage.how_used: Applied to Jesus's suffering, death, and resurrection as fulfillment of prophecy
scripture_usage.interpretation_given: The Suffering Servant is Jesus who bore humanity's sins through his death
scripture_usage.impact_description: Central text for Christian atonement theology

perspective_views.orthodox: Prophetic anticipation of Christ's redemptive suffering
perspective_views.catholic: Prediction of Christ's passion and vicarious atonement
perspective_views.protestant: Key proof-text for penal substitutionary atonement
perspective_views.jewish: Refers to Israel collectively or righteous remnant, not individual Messiah
perspective_views.academic: Pre-Christian interpretations varied; Christian reading influential but not original meaning

scripture_usage.passage_text: My God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me?... I am poured out like water, and all my bones are out of joint... they pierced my hands and my feet... They part my garments among them, and cast lots upon my vesture.
scripture_usage.how_used: Jesus quoted Psalm 22:1 from the cross; Gospel writers applied various verses to crucifixion details
scripture_usage.interpretation_given: David's psalm prophetically describes the Messiah's crucifixion
scripture_usage.impact_description: Shaped Christian understanding of crucifixion as prophesied event

perspective_views.orthodox: Messianic prophecy fulfilled in Christ's passion
perspective_views.catholic: Prophetic psalm; Jesus reciting it reveals crucifixion's meaning
perspective_views.jewish: Davidic psalm of lament; not messianic prediction
perspective_views.academic: Psalm of individual lament; Christian reading typological rather than predictive

scripture_usage.passage_text: And it shall come to pass afterward, that I will pour out my spirit upon all flesh; and your sons and your daughters shall prophesy, your old men shall dream dreams, your young men shall see visions: And also upon the servants and upon the handmaids in those days will I pour out my spirit.
scripture_usage.how_used: Peter quoted this passage to explain the Pentecost events
scripture_usage.interpretation_given: The outpouring of the Spirit at Pentecost fulfills Joel's prophecy; the last days have begun
scripture_usage.impact_description: Established Pentecost as fulfillment of prophecy; inaugurated eschatology

perspective_views.orthodox: Prophetic fulfillment; beginning of the age of the Spirit
perspective_views.catholic: Pentecost fulfills prophecy; Spirit continues in Church
perspective_views.protestant: Fulfillment inaugurating church age; some see ongoing, others initial fulfillment
perspective_views.jewish: Eschatological prophecy not yet fulfilled; awaits future realization
perspective_views.academic: Apocalyptic prophecy; Christian application reflects their eschatological self-understanding

scripture_usage.passage_text: Now the LORD had said unto Abram, Get thee out of thy country... And I will make of thee a great nation, and I will bless thee... and in thee shall all families of the earth be blessed.
scripture_usage.how_used: Used to argue that Gentile blessing was always God's intention
scripture_usage.interpretation_given: The Abrahamic covenant anticipated the inclusion of all nations through faith
scripture_usage.impact_description: Provided scriptural basis for Gentile inclusion without Torah observance

perspective_views.orthodox: God's universal plan revealed from beginning
perspective_views.protestant: Gospel preached beforehand to Abraham; justification by faith
perspective_views.jewish: Promise to Abraham fulfilled through Jewish people; nations blessed through Israel
perspective_views.academic: Patriarchal promise; Christian reading extends original meaning

scripture_usage.passage_text: The LORD thy God will raise up unto thee a Prophet from the midst of thee, of thy brethren, like unto me; unto him ye shall hearken... I will raise them up a Prophet from among their brethren, like unto thee, and will put my words in his mouth.
scripture_usage.how_used: Applied to Jesus as the prophet like Moses (Acts 3:22-23, 7:37)
scripture_usage.interpretation_given: Jesus is the definitive prophet promised by Moses
scripture_usage.impact_description: Established Moses-Jesus typology in Christian thought

perspective_views.orthodox: Christ as prophet, priest, and king fulfills all Old Testament types
perspective_views.catholic: Jesus as new Moses giving new law
perspective_views.jewish: Refers to succession of prophets generally; not single messianic figure
perspective_views.academic: Promise of prophetic succession; Christian messianic reading secondary
